intro: Salpiglossis lomana, commonly known as the Lomana lipped bellflower, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the family Campanulaceae and is characterized by its striking, tubular flowers that range in color from pink to red. The plant typically grows as an annual or biennial, reaching heights of 30 to 60 centimeters. Its foliage consists of lance-shaped leaves that are often hairy and arranged alternately along the stem. The flowers bloom in late summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
